awd_titl_txt: Engaging and Retaining Women Veterans in the STEM Workforce: An NSF INCLUDES DCL Conference to Broaden the Pipeline from Service to STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
This NSF INCLUDES Conference on Engaging and Retaining Women Veterans in the STEM Workforce is created in response to the NSF INCLUDES program's Dear Colleague Letter (DCL): Supporting the Re-Entry of Women and Women Veterans in the STEM Workforce through NSF INCLUDES (NSF 19-038). The Education Development Center (EDC) will develop and host this convening to address the unique barriers and opportunities for women veterans, particularly those from populations underrepresented in STEM fields, to (re)engage in the STEM workforce. While much is known about the needs of veterans and the transition from service to civilian life, including the specific needs of women veterans, there is still much work to be done to ensure that those who have served the United States can leverage their experiences and leadership expertise into economic opportunities. This convening will raise awareness and provide information to advance services to women veterans and the STEM workforce by providing an opportunity for the various stakeholders to review and analyze the body of knowledge that currently exists, stimulate new ideas and development, and facilitate collaboration across the different stakeholder groups and efforts aimed at helping women veterans transition to civilian life and careers. 

This convening will bring together researchers, practitioners, and policymakers; leadership representing universities and community colleges, nonprofit organizations, and federal agencies that serve veterans; and women veterans to address issues through an intersectional lens. The multi-stakeholder group will take a comprehensive approach toward bringing actionable change toward strengthening the pipeline from service to STEM for women veterans. The goals of this convening will be to (1) synthesize the disparate constellations of services available to women veterans, especially those regarding STEM workforce reentry, (2) develop products and publications that will galvanize industry and academia to approach veteran workforce reentry with renewed purpose, and (3) inspire transformative innovation through thoughtful and wide-reaching dissemination of these products. The effort will ultimately lead to a comprehensive report and webinar series that will further the national dialogue about the importance of policies and programs to support women veterans in seeking greater economic opportunities through STEM work.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The women who serve our country deserve every opportunity to successfully transition from military to civilian life and the workforce. Moreover, they bring many skills and strengths to the STEM workforce. Recognizing the importance of engaging Veterans in the STEM workforce, in 2020, Congress enacted the Supporting Veterans in STEM Careers Act, which directs the National Science Foundation (NSF) to “encourage Veterans to study and pursue careers in STEM and computer science”. Education Development Center (EDC) proposed Engaging and Retaining Female Veterans in the STEM Workforce: An NSF INCLUDES DCL Conference to Strengthen the Pipeline from Service to STEM to identify and address the unique barriers and opportunities for female Veterans, particularly those from populations underrepresented in STEM fields, to engaging in the STEM workforce after service. This convening sought to bring together researchers, practitioners, and policymakers; leadership representing universities and community colleges, nonprofit organizations, and federal agencies that serve Veterans; and female Veterans to (1) synthesize the resources and services available to female Veterans, especially those regarding entry into and persistence in the STEM workforce, (2) develop and disseminate products and publications that would galvanize industry and academia to better support the entry of female Veterans in the STEM workforce, and (3) inspire transformative innovation through thoughtful and wide-reaching dissemination of these products. The ultimate goal of this convening and dissemination of the project's findings would be to inspire stakeholders from different fields to look at what has worked well to boost female Veterans’ participation and success in STEM careers and replicate and support these efforts. 

EDC is a nationally recognized leader in the effective leadership and management of national and international outcome-focused meetings and in the development of professional learning communities and innovation networks designed to promote rapid learning, encourage innovation, and foster shared ownership and leadership of key activities and resources. The PIs for this convening are experienced in convening stakeholders in relevant program communities, such as NSF’s ITEST (Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers) program and the Amgen Biotech Experience science education outreach program funded by the biopharmaceutical leader Amgen. The goal of this convening was to advance services to female Veterans and the STEM workforce itself by providing an opportunity for the various stakeholders to review and analyze the body of knowledge that currently exists, provoke new ideas and development, and facilitate collaboration across the different stakeholder groups and efforts aimed at helping female Veterans transition to civilian life and careers. The advisory committee that designed and facilitated the convening represents the range of issues involved in attracting and retaining female Veterans in the STEM workforce, from the transition to civilian life to STEM education and the STEM workforce. EDC brought its capacity and access to necessary resources to conduct this work, serving as a backbone for the project.

While much is known about the needs of Veterans and the transition from service to civilian life, including the specific needs of female Veterans, there is still much work to be done to ensure that those who have served our country can leverage their experiences and leadership expertise into economic opportunities. In particular, we need to provide greater opportunities to Veterans and create better pathways for female Veterans to enter the STEM workforce. As a result of this project, we were able to gather and analyze information about the current state of this topic, identify opportunities to advance this work, and pave the way for greater collaboration among those organizations that seek to support the unique needs of women Veterans. While this work is far from complete, we hope that the resources developed from this convening can strengthen the pipeline from service to STEM for female Veterans. Through our dissemination efforts, we have shared opportunities to make an impact with the National Science Foundation (NSF), federal agencies serving the military and Veterans, industry, higher education, and others interested in broadening participation in the STEM workforce. The work of this project continues to be critical and is timely given the growing diversity of the U.S. military and Veteran population as well as efforts to engage members of the military and our Veteran population in the STEM workforce.


Last Modified: 09/30/2022
Modified by: Rebecca P Lewis
